page.title: 07ERITH DEEP WHARF
page.content: The paper stored at Erith Deep Wharf Storage Depot comes from Finland. Pine trees are cut down and pulled by tractor to the lake. They are tied together like a huge raft. When they arrive at one of the ten to twelve paper mills that are scattered all over Finland they are made into paper pulp. Chalk and bleach are added. The paper is dried and cut to correct lengths, then bundled off to Rauma, the port where they begin their journey by ship. It comes to Erith once a week carrying 4,000 tons of paper. At Erith the reels are transported by a moveable crane into the storage depot. There they stay until needed by a national magazine or newspaper. The paper is moved by hydraulic truck. Paper is transported by truck to Fleet Street.
